organizations.name: labour’s shadow minister for trade unions & civil society

text:
Jeremy Corbyn will win Labour leadership contest and his critics must accept it says MP 05:00, 21 Sep 2016 By Jonathan Walker Wansbeck MP Ian Lavery urges Labour to unite around Corbyn who he says will also make compromises Share Get daily news by email Laura Dale/PA Wire Labour party leader Jeremy Corbyn arrives at Labour Party HQ in Westminster, London 
Jeremy Corbyn is set to win Labour’s leadership election - and his critics must accept the result, according to one of his vocal supporters. 
Ian Lavery , Labour MP for Wansbeck and Labour’s Shadow Minister for Trade Unions & Civil Society, said Mr Corbyn’s critics must “come to terms” with the fact that he was the overwhelming choice of party members. 
But he also said Mr Corbyn was willing to “learn from his mistakes” and make peace with his opponents. 
While the result of Labour’s leadership contest won’t be announced until Saturday, Mr Corbyn is widely expected to be declared the winner - meaning he has won contests two years running. 
And his challenger, Labour MP Owen Smith, last night issued a statement defending his decision to stand which could be seen as a tacit admission that he expected his bid to be unsuccessful. 
Labour’s ruling National Executive Committee (NEC) met in London to discuss moves to restore party unity amid warnings of an early general election. 
But the NEC failed to reach agreement, despite eight hours of discussion. 
Further talks will now take place ahead of the next NEC meeting on Saturday, at the party's conference. 
Deputy leader Tom Watson was seeking a decision on proposals allow MPs to elect the shadow cabinet, which he said could help “put the band back together” and bring talent from all sides of the party into Jeremy Corbyn’s top team. Jane Barlow/PA Wire Owen Smith and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn 
In practice, it would give Labour MPs more say over the way the party was run. 
The NEC also considered proposals from Mr Watson to change the way in which the party elects its leader and put more power over the choice back into the hands of MPs and unions. 
But Mr Corbyn was believed to be arguing that any changes to the party’s democratic structures should be part of a wider review to take place after the conference is over. 
And he was backed by Mr Lavery, who said any changes needed more consideration. 
Mr Lavery said: “There should be more time for discussion. We are trying to rush this through too early. 
The most important thing is the need for the arty to unite. There needs to be a commitment from all sides of the party. 
“Jeremy can’t really do any more than he’s doing in terms of holding the olive branch out to people who perhaps haven’t been supportive in the past.” 
Mr Corbyn was willing to listen to advice from experienced Labour figures, Mr Lavery said. 
“Jeremy’s doing everything he possibly can to unite the party. He’s saying he wants the party to be united, he’s willing to learn from his mistakes and he wants to learn from senior politicians who have been in senior posts who can advise him on the best way forward.” MP Ian Lavery 
Mr Lavery said Mr Corbyn would win the leadership election. 
“Jeremy will win this election probably by a bigger margin [than last time]. 
“People are going to have to come to terms with that. That’s what the members of the party want.” 
Meanwhile, in a letter to party members, Mr Smith said he would continue fighting for “a positive programme for a future Labour government” regardless of the outcome of the leadership election. 
He said: “I entered this contest because I want to see a Labour government again. I want to see a radical, transformative government that can change our country for the better and bring an end to another generation of Tory rule.” 
Mr Smith highlighted his proposals for a £200bn investment programme, an extra £60bn for our NHS and another Brexit referendum, adding: “These ideas will remain as relevant after this contest as they have been during this contest . . . whatever the outcome of this contest I will continue to make these arguments and do all I can to see us back in government.” Jane Barlow/PA Wire Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn Photo by Jane Barlow/PA Wire 
Labour Deputy Leader Tom Watson insisted Mr Corbyn could “very easily” be Labour’s next Prime Minister as long as the party unites concentrates on fighting the Tories, in an interview with BBC Radio 4. 
He said: “I think Jeremy could easily be a Labour Prime Minister. 
“I think we’ve got change what we do, how we campaign . . . whoever wins that leadership we’ve got to swing in around that leader.” 
And he said he was “very concerned” by suggestions that some Labour MPs could be deselected. 
Mr Watson said: “If energy is expended trying to undermine political opponents in your own party then obviously that’s time not spent characterising and attacking your opponents.” 
Predicting that Prime Minister Theresa May could call an early general election, he said: “Our sole focus after Saturday must be on taking on the Tory government.”
